definitions: collective agricultural community in Israel based on socialist principles and communal living
examples: She spent a summer working at a kibbutz in the Negev desert
The kibbutz produced organic vegetables for local markets

definitions: forceful blow or strike made with the foot
sharp stimulating effect or feeling of excitement from something
informal complaint or objection about something unfair or unsatisfactory
examples: The soccer player delivered a powerful kick to the ball
The horse gave a violent kick that damaged the stable door
This new coffee blend has quite a kick to it
She gets a real kick out of performing on stage
His only kick was about the early morning schedule
They filed a formal kick against the new regulations

definitions: payment made illegally to someone in return for facilitating a transaction or business deal
sudden backward movement or recoil from machinery or weapons when operated
examples: The contractor was caught accepting kickbacks from suppliers
Politicians were investigated for receiving kickbacks on construction contracts
The chainsaw had a dangerous kickback that injured his arm
Always be prepared for kickback when operating power tools

definitions: player who kicks the ball especially in American football for field goals
unexpected or surprising twist element that changes a situation dramatically
small outboard motor used as auxiliary power on boats
examples: The team's kicker scored three field goals in the championship game
She worked as the placekicker for her college football team
The kicker was that he already knew about the surprise party
Here's the real kicker - they were twins separated at birth
The sailboat had a small kicker for emergencies
We used the kicker motor when the wind died down

definitions: action or process of striking something with the foot repeatedly
state of being alive active or functioning vigorously
examples: The kicking of the horse made it dangerous to approach
Excessive kicking damaged the locker room door
The old engine is still alive and kicking after fifty years
The party was still kicking when we arrived at midnight

definitions: start of a football or soccer game when the ball is first kicked
beginning or launch of a project campaign or organized activity
examples: The kickoff is scheduled for three o'clock this afternoon
They won the coin toss and chose to receive the kickoff
The campaign kickoff attracted hundreds of supporters downtown
We're planning a kickoff meeting for the new project Monday

definitions: informal term for a child or young person
young goat especially one under a year old
soft smooth leather made from young goat skin
examples: The kids played in the backyard all afternoon
She has three kids in elementary school
The farm had several kids born this spring
The mother goat was nursing her newborn kid
Her kid gloves were perfect for the formal occasion
The purse was made from genuine kid leather

definitions: informal affectionate term for a young child typically under school age
examples: The kiddie pool was perfect for toddlers learning to swim
There's a special kiddie menu with smaller portions

definitions: criminal who illegally seizes and detains a person against their will often for ransom
examples: The kidnapper demanded a million dollars for the executive's release
Police arrested the kidnapper after a three-day manhunt

definitions: criminal act of unlawfully seizing and carrying away a person by force or fraud
examples: The kidnapping shocked the entire community last summer
They were charged with kidnapping and extortion

definitions: vital organ that filters waste from blood and produces urine in vertebrates
person's temperament nature or disposition especially of a particular kind
examples: The patient needed a kidney transplant to survive
Both kidneys were functioning normally after the surgery
They were men of the same kidney with similar values
She was not of the kidney to give up easily

definitions: act of causing death or destroying something living
animal that has been hunted and killed especially by a predator
examples: The lion made a quick kill of the wounded antelope
The assassination was a professional kill
The leopard dragged its kill up into the tree
Eagles often defend their kill from scavengers

definitions: person or animal that kills another living being intentionally
disease agent or factor that causes death or is extremely dangerous
something extremely difficult impressive or exhausting in informal usage
examples: The serial killer was finally captured after years of investigation
The lion is an efficient killer in the wild
Heart disease remains the number one killer in developed nations
This new virus could be a potential killer
That final exam was a real killer
Her new dress is an absolute killer

definitions: act of causing the death of a person or animal intentionally
large profit or financial success made quickly in informal usage
examples: The killing occurred in broad daylight downtown
Trophy hunting involves the killing of wild animals
He made a killing in the stock market last year
They made an absolute killing on that real estate deal

definitions: furnace or oven for burning baking or drying especially for pottery or bricks
examples: The pottery was fired in the kiln at extremely high temperatures
The brick kiln operated continuously for three days

definitions: informal shortened form of kilogram equal to one thousand grams
examples: She bought two kilos of apples at the market
The package weighs about five kilos

definitions: basic unit of mass in the metric system equal to one thousand grams
examples: The newborn baby weighed three kilograms at birth
Gold is often measured in kilograms for large transactions

definitions: metric unit of length equal to one thousand meters or approximately 0.62 miles
examples: The marathon covers a distance of 42.195 kilometers
The nearest town is about ten kilometers away

definitions: British spelling of kilometer a metric unit equal to one thousand meters
examples: The speed limit is eighty kilometres per hour here
We walked five kilometres along the coastal path

definitions: unit of electrical power equal to one thousand watts
examples: The solar panels generate five kilowatts of electricity daily
Our monthly usage averages 300 kilowatt-hours

definitions: knee-length pleated skirt traditionally worn by men in Scotland made of tartan wool
examples: He wore a traditional kilt to the Highland Games
The bagpiper's kilt displayed his clan's tartan pattern

definitions: good working order or proper condition usually used in phrases like off kilter
examples: The earthquake knocked everything out of kilter
Something feels off kilter with the engine today

definitions: traditional Japanese ankle-length robe with wide sleeves worn with a sash
examples: She wore an elegant silk kimono to the tea ceremony
The vintage kimono featured beautiful cherry blossom embroidery

definitions: one's relatives or family members collectively related by blood or marriage
examples: All her kin gathered for the family reunion last summer
He had no living kin after his parents died

definitions: school or class for young children usually ages four to six before first grade
examples: She teaches kindergarten at the local elementary school
The kindergarten curriculum includes basic reading and math skills

definitions: small dry sticks or twigs used to start a fire
examples: We gathered kindling from the forest floor to start the campfire
The kindling caught fire quickly with just one match

definitions: group of people with similar interests beliefs or characteristics
one's family and relations considered as a group
examples: She found kindred spirits at the writers' workshop
They were kindred souls who understood each other perfectly
All his kindred came to celebrate his ninetieth birthday
The kindred gathered to discuss the family estate

definitions: male ruler of an independent state especially one who inherits by right
playing card bearing the picture of a king ranking above queen
most important chess piece that must be protected from checkmate
person or thing regarded as finest or most important in sphere
examples: The king ruled the nation for forty prosperous years
King Henry VIII had six wives during his reign
He played the king of hearts to win the trick
She held three kings in her poker hand
Moving the king to safety is crucial in chess endgame
The white king was trapped in checkmate
Elvis Presley was known as the king of rock and roll
The lion is considered the king of the jungle

definitions: country state or territory ruled by a king or queen
highest taxonomic category in biological classification of living things
realm or sphere in which someone or something holds dominant position
examples: The United Kingdom includes England Scotland Wales and Northern Ireland
The ancient kingdom stretched from the mountains to the sea
Fungi belong to their own kingdom separate from plants and animals
The animal kingdom includes millions of different species
The kitchen was her kingdom where she ruled absolutely
In the kingdom of the blind the one-eyed man is king

definitions: small bright-colored bird with large head and long bill that dives for fish
examples: The kingfisher perched on a branch above the stream
A flash of blue revealed a kingfisher diving for minnows

definitions: person who has great influence in choosing leaders especially in politics or business
examples: The party chairman was considered the kingmaker in selecting candidates
Media moguls often act as kingmakers in modern elections

definitions: main bolt in a mechanism especially one connecting vehicle to its wheels
person who controls an illegal organization especially drug trafficking
most important person in a group or undertaking
examples: The truck's kingpin needed replacement after years of wear
The kingpin connects the trailer to the tractor unit
Police arrested the drug kingpin after a lengthy investigation
The kingpin controlled the entire smuggling operation
She was the kingpin of the whole marketing department
He became the kingpin in the company's expansion plans

definitions: state dignity or office of being a king and the power associated with it
examples: He renounced his claim to kingship to marry a commoner
The kingship passed to his eldest son upon his death

definitions: sharp twist or curve in something that is otherwise straight
unusual sexual preference or quirk in someone's personality or behavior
painful muscle spasm or crick especially in the neck or back
examples: There was a kink in the garden hose blocking water flow
The wire had developed several kinks from improper storage
Everyone has their little kinks and peculiarities
His kinks made him an interesting but challenging partner
She woke up with a terrible kink in her neck
The massage therapist worked out the kink in his shoulder

definitions: blood relationship or connection between people descended from common ancestors
feeling of being close or connected to other people or things
examples: DNA testing can establish kinship between distant relatives
The kinship system determines inheritance in many cultures
She felt an immediate kinship with other cancer survivors
There's a natural kinship between artists and musicians

definitions: man who is one of a person's blood relations or family members
examples: His kinsman from Scotland came to visit last summer
The elderly kinsman left his fortune to charity

definitions: small structure with open sides used for selling things or providing information
computer terminal providing information or services in a public place
examples: She bought a newspaper from the kiosk at the train station
The food kiosk in the mall sells fresh smoothies
Travelers can check in using the automated kiosk at the airport
The information kiosk displays maps and tourist attractions

definitions: destiny or fate especially a predetermined course of events often seen as divinely ordained
examples: Meeting her felt like kismet after all those years
He believed it was kismet that brought them together

definitions: act or practice of touching with the lips as sign of affection or greeting
examples: Public kissing is frowned upon in some cultures
The kissing scene in the movie was very romantic

definitions: set of articles or equipment needed for a specific purpose
young of certain fur-bearing animals especially fox beaver or rabbit
set of clothing and equipment for a particular activity
examples: The first aid kit contained bandages and antiseptic
She bought a complete sewing kit for her craft projects
The fox returned to her den to nurse her kits
Three beaver kits were born in the spring
The football kit includes jersey shorts and socks
Soldiers must maintain their kit in perfect condition

definitions: room or area where food is prepared and cooked in a house or establishment
examples: The kitchen was equipped with modern stainless steel appliances
She spent most of her time experimenting with recipes in the kitchen

definitions: light frame covered with paper or cloth flown in wind at end of string
medium to large bird of prey with long wings and forked tail
fraudulent check or illegal use of credit to obtain money
examples: Children flew colorful kites in the park on windy days
The kite soared high above the beach
A red kite circled overhead searching for prey
The kite's distinctive forked tail made identification easy
He was arrested for kiting checks between multiple accounts
The company collapsed due to kiting and financial fraud

definitions: art objects or design considered to be in poor taste but appreciated ironically
examples: The gift shop was full of tourist kitsch and souvenirs
Some people collect kitsch as a form of ironic art

definitions: young domestic cat especially one less than one year old
examples: The kitten played with a ball of yarn for hours
We adopted two kittens from the animal shelter

definitions: pool of money for communal use built from contributions
informal or affectionate name for a cat or kitten
examples: Everyone contributed ten dollars to the office kitty for parties
The poker kitty grew larger with each hand played
Here kitty kitty called the child to her pet
The kitty curled up on the warm windowsill

definitions: flightless bird native to New Zealand with hair-like feathers
oval fruit with fuzzy brown skin and green flesh with black seeds
informal term for a person from New Zealand
examples: The kiwi is New Zealand's national bird and symbol
Kiwis are nocturnal and rarely seen in the wild
She added sliced kiwi to the fruit salad
Kiwis are rich in vitamin C and fiber
As a proud Kiwi he supported the All Blacks rugby team
Many Kiwis travel overseas for work experience

definitions: acquired or natural skill at performing a task with ease and expertise
examples: She has a real knack for learning foreign languages quickly
He developed a knack for fixing old computers

definitions: bag with shoulder straps carried on the back used especially for hiking
examples: The hiker's knapsack contained food water and camping gear
Students carried their books in knapsacks

definitions: dishonest or unscrupulous man often used in archaic contexts
jack in a deck of playing cards in British usage
examples: The knave tried to cheat the merchant out of his gold
Shakespeare's plays often featured knaves and rogues
She played the knave of hearts to take the trick
The knave ranks between ten and queen in card games

definitions: joint between the thigh and lower leg in humans and other animals
part of a garment covering the knee or something resembling a bent knee
examples: She injured her knee playing basketball last week
The doctor examined the swelling in his right knee
The jeans had holes at both knees from wear
The pipe had a knee joint for changing direction
